turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: That was how I ended up in a barber shop quartet in Skokie, Illinois.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: This is totally irrelevant.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Oh, but it's not. If I hadn't been nailed in Illinois for running a three card monte in between sets, I never would have took off for New York. I never would have met Keaton, see. That barber shop quartet was the reason for everything.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Can we just get back to Kobayashi?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: The quartet is part of the bit about Kobayashi. The quartet was in my file, along with every other thing I had done since high school, see? Aliases, middle- men. They knew me better than I did. They knew all of us.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: You're stalling, Verbal.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Give a guy a break, huh?

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Then what?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: McManus was furious. He was talking about tracking him down and ripping his heart out and all sorts of shit. That night we got the call.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: What call?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Kobayashi told us where we could find Fenster.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I wanted to. I thought we could make it.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Why didn't you say anything?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I tried, believe me, but Keaton wouldn't have it. It was too far-fetched for him. Keaton was a grounded guy. An ex-cop. To a cop, the explanation is never that complicated. It's always simple. There's

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: A man in a suit with a slim build. Tall.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Wait a minute.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: I don't have a minute. Are you saying it was Keyser Soze? You told the D.A. you didn't know who it was.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Don't shine me, Verbal. No more stalling. You know what I'm getting at.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I don't.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: YES YOU DO. YOU KNOW WHAT I'M GETTING AT. THE TRUTH. TRY TO TELL ME YOU DIDN'T KNOW. TRY TO TELL ME YOU SAW SOMEONE KILL KEATON .

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: TRY TO REEF LYING TO ME NOW. I KNOW EVERYTHING .

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: YOU KNOW. YOU'VE KNOWN THIS WHOLE FUCKING TIME. GIVE IT TO ME.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I don't understand what you're saying. I saw Keaton get shot, I swear to you.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Then why didn't you help him?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I WAS AFRAID, OKAY? Somehow, I was sure it was Keyser Soze at that point. I couldn't bring myself to raise my gun to him.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: But Keaton...

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: It was Keyser Soze, Agent Kujan. I mean the Devil himself. How do you shoot the Devil in the back?

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: He was a stool pigeon for the Justice Department. He swore out a statement to Federal Marshals that he had seen and could positively identify one Keyser Soze and had intimate knowledge of his business, including, but not exclusive to, drug trafficking and murder.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I never heard of him.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: His own people were selling him to a gang of Hungarians. Most likely the same Hungarians that Sate all but wiped out back in Turkey. The money wasn't there for dope. The Hungarians were going to buy the one guy that could finger Soze for them.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I said I never heard of him.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: But Keaton had. Edie Finneran was his extradition advisor. She knew who he was and what he knew.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I don't

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: There were no drugs on that boat. It was a hit. A suicide mission to whack out the one man that could finger Keyser Soze so Sate had a few thieves put to it. Men he knew he could march into certain death.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: But how - wait. You're saying SOZE sent                  t us to kill someone?

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Verbal, he left you behind for a reason. If you all knew Soze could find you anywhere, why was he ready to send you off with the money when he could have used you to take the boat?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: He wanted me to live.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Why did he want you to live? A one-time dirty cop without a loyalty in the world finds it in his heart to save a worthless rat-cripple? No, sir. Why'

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Edie.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: I don't buy that reform story for a minute. And even if I did, I certainly don't believe he would send you to protect her. So why?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Because he was my friend.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: No, Verbal. You weren't friends. Keaton didn't have friends. He saved you because he wanted it that way. It was his will.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Keaton was Keyser Soze

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: NO.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: NO, NO, NO, NO, NO.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: THE KIND OF MAN THAT COULD HAVE KILLED EDIE FINNERAN.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Edie...

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: He used all of you to get him on that boat. He couldn't get on alone and he had to pull the trigger himself to make sure he got his man. The one man that could identify him.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: This is all bullshit.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: He left you to stay behind and tell us he was dead. You saw him die, right? Or did you? You had to hide when the first police cars showed up. You heard the shot, just before the fire but you didn't see him die.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I knew him. He would never -

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: He programmed you to tell us just what he wanted you to. Customs has been

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: If he's dead, Verbal - if what you say is true, then it won't matter. It was his idea to hit the Taxi Service in New York, wasn't it? Tell me the truth.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: It was all Keaton. We followed him from the beginning.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I didn't know. I saw him die. I believe he's dead. Christ

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Why lie about everything else, then?

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: You know what it's like, Agent Kujan, to know you'll never be good? Not good like you. You got good all fucked around. I mean a stand up guy. I grew up knowing I was never going to be good at anything 'cause I was a cripple. Shit, I wasn't

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: You're not safe on your own.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: You think he's..?

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Is he Keyser Soze I don't know, Verbal. It seems to me that Keyser Sate is a shield. Like you said, a spook story, but I know Keaton - and someone out there is pulling strings for you. Stay here and let us protect you.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I'm not bait. No way. I post today.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: You posted twenty minutes ago. Captain Leo wants you out of here a.s.a.p., unless you turn state's.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: I'11 take my chances, thank you. It's tougher to buy the cheapest bag-man than it is to buy a cop.

turns.speaker: KUJAN
turns.text: Where are you going to go, Verbal? You gonna run? Turn states evidence. You might never see trial. If somebody wants to get you, you know They'll get you out there.

turns.speaker: VERBAL
turns.text: Maybe so, but I'm no rat, Agent Kujan. You tricked me, that's all. I won't keep my mouth shut 'cause I'm scared. I'11 keep it shut 'cause I let Keaton down by getting caught - Edie Finneran too. And if they kill me, it's

turns.speaker: VOICE #1
turns.text: My client offers his full cooperation in these proceedings. In exchange, his testimony is to be sealed and all matters incriminating to himself are to be rendered inadmissible.

turns.speaker: VOICE #2
turns.text: The district attorney's office will comply provided -

turns.speaker: VOICE #1
turns.text: No provisions, nothing. My clients testimony for his immunity.

turns.speaker: VOICE #2
turns.text: May-I be frank, Counselor? I suspect your political power as much as I respect it. I don't know why Mr. Kint has so many faceless allies in City Hall, and I don't care. The embarrassment he helped cause the city of New York will not happen here.

turns.speaker: VOICE #1
turns.text: Immunity.

turns.speaker: VOICE #2
turns.text: Counselor, I will prosecute your client.

turns.speaker: VOICE #1
turns.text: Then prosecute. I will be very impressed to see if the District Attorney manages to bring in twenty-seven simultaneous counts of murder against one man with cerebral palsy. I would think a man with your job would agree with these alleged "faceless people in City Hall" you mention.

turns.speaker: VOICE #2
turns.text: I'11 take my chances then. I'11 feel safer without a job if a man like Mr. Kint is behind bars.

turns.speaker: VOICE #1
turns.text: Mr. Kint will plead guilty to weapons possession.

turns.speaker: VOICE #2
turns.text: You're joking.

turns.speaker: VOICE #1
turns.text: Weapons. Misdemeanor one.

turns.speaker: VOICE #2
turns.text: Counselor, you're insulting me.

turns.speaker: VOICE #1
turns.text: Counselor, you're bluffing. Shall I push for misdemeanor two?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Mr. Abraham...

turns.speaker: ABRAMS
turns.text: Abrams...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Abrams.  Yes.  How are you today?

turns.speaker: ABRAMS
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Good.    You ever been inside a hospital?

turns.speaker: ABRAMS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Ah.  How did they treat you?

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: Why did he go to see Mary Rooney?

turns.speaker: YOUNG LAWYER
turns.text: She's the only nurse who isn't testifying for the Doctors.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: What did he find?

turns.speaker: YOUNG LAWYER
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: How good's your intelligence?

turns.speaker: YOUNG LAWYER
turns.text: Very good.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: And so what is the rest of his case aside from Dr. Thompson?

turns.speaker: YOUNG LAWYER
turns.text: As far as we know, nothing.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: He was accused of jury tampering.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: Accused.  Not indicted.  He resigned the firm.  Divorced nineteen seventy.  Galvin worked with Michael Morrissey until Morrissey retired in 'seventy-eight.  Since then he's been on his own.  Four cases before the Circuit Court.  He lost them all.  He drinks.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: Four cases in three years ...

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: The man's an ambulance chaser ...

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: ... tell me about this case.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: This is a nuisance suit.  He's looking for small change.  He's asking for six hundred thousand and betting we don't want to go to court.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: No -- we don't want this case in court.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: Neither does he.  That's where he loses.  This man's scared to death to go to court.  We only have to call his bluff.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: I want to settle this thing and be done with it.  I don't want the Archdiocese exposed.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: No.  Absolutely, and we're going to see that it is not.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: So what I want to do is stop it here.  I'm going to make him an offer.  I want to do it myself.  I want it to come from me.

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: All right.  But let's keep the price down.  I've called Ed Concannon.  He recommends that we continue to respond as if we're going to trial.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: If we were to go to trial, would we win the case?

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: Well, of course, it's always dangerous ...

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: I know that answer.  If we went to trial would we win?

turns.speaker: ALITO
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: It's a generous offer, Mr. Galvin... ...nothing can make the woman well...but we try to compensate...to make a gesture...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: How did you settle on the amount?

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: We thought it was just.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You thought it was just.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Because it struck me how neatly 'three' went into the amount.  Two Hundred Ten Thousand.  That would mean I keep seventy.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: That was our insurance company's recommendation.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.  It would be.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: Nothing that we can do can make that woman well.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: And no one will know the truth.

turns.speaker: BISHOP
turns.text: What is the truth?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That that poor girl put her trust in the hands of two men who took her life, she's in a coma, her life is gone.  She has no family, she has no home, she's tied to a machine, she has no friends --and the people who should care for her:  her Doctors, and you, and me, have been bought off to look the other way.  We have been paid to look the other way.  I came in here to take your money.   I brought snapshots to show you. So I could get your money.   I can't take it.  If I take it. If I take that money I'm lost. I'm just going to be a rich ambulance chaser.    I can't do it. I can't take it.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Mickey told me to come back to work.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: ... here's your mail, call Mrs. Doneghy ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... yes.  Get her on the phone ...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: ... that was a Dr. David Gruber's office ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Gruber...

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Mickey told him to call.  'He's some very hotshot surgeon at Mass. Commonwealth.  He wants to meet with you at seven tonight re testimony in the case of Deborah Ann Kaye.  You meet him at the hospital.'

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... he wants to testify ...?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: It looks that way.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You know what that would mean?  To get somebody from a Boston hospital to say he'll testify?

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: ... a Mrs. Doneghy called ... I told you that.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: This is going to drive the ante up.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Frank Galvin's ... who's calling please?  Bishop Brophy's office ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That's the call that I'm waiting for.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: What does it mean?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: They want to settle.    It means a lot of money.

turns.speaker: CLAIRE
turns.text: Does that mean I'm back for awhile?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: No, actually, she was referred to me.  She was Dr. Hagman's patient...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Don't equivocate.  Be positive. Just tell the truth.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Whatever the `truth' is, let's hear that.  You were her doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Say it.

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: I was her doctor.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You were the anesthesiologist at her delivery May twelfth, nineteen seventy...

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: ...I was one of a group of...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Answer affirmatively.  Simply. Keep those answers to three words. You weren't `part of a group,' you were her anesthesiologist.  Isn't that right?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You were there to help Dr. Marx deliver her baby.  Were you not?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Anything special about the case?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: When she...

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Thank you.  When Debby...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Dr. Towler, who was in the operating room with you?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Ms. Nevins, nurse-anesthetist; Dr.Marx, of course...

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Mary Rooney, the obstetrical nurse...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: What did these people do when her heart stopped?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: We went to Code Blue...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: `Code Blue,' what does that mean...?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: It's a common medical expression, it's a crash program to restore the heartbeat.  Dr. Marx cut an airway in her trachea, to get her oxygen, her and the baby...Ms.Nevins...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Why wasn't she getting oxygen...?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Well, many reasons, actually...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Tell me one?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: She'd aspirated vomitus into her mask...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: She THREW UP IN HER MASK.  Let's cut the bullshit.  Say it:  She THREW UP IN HER MASK.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...and her heart stopped and she wasn't getting oxygen.

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: And what did your team do...

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Well, we...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...You brought thirty years of medical experience to bear.  Isn't that what you did?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...A patient riddled with complications, questionable information on her, on her admitting form...

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: ...We did everything we could...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...to save her and to save the baby.  Is that...

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You reached down into death.  Now, isn't that right?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: My God, we tried to save her...You can't know...You can't know...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Tell us.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Ed Concannon.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Frank Galvin.  We've met before.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Objection, we've...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...to get her heartbeat back...?

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: We've touched on this, his own witness has said...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...almost nine minutes...  causing brain damage.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Your Honor...!  Your Honor...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: And you would come here, and on a slip of memory four years ago, you'd ruin their lives.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Dr. Thompson, just so the Jury knows, you never treated Deborah Ann Kaye.  Is that correct?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: That is correct.  I was engaged to render an opinion.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Engaged to render an opinion.  For a price.  Is that correct?  You're being paid to be here today?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Just as you are, Sir...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Are you board-certified in anesthesiology, Doctor?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: No, I am not.  It's quite common in New York State...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...I'm sure it is, but this is Massachusetts, Doctor.  Certified in Internal Medicine?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Neurology?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Orthopedics?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I'm just an M.D.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Do you know Dr. Robert Towler...?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I know of him.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: How is that?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Through, through his book.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: What book is that?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Meth...Methodology and Technique...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...of Anesthesiology?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: `Methodology and Techniques of Anesthesiology.'  Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: How old are you?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I am seventy-four years old.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Uh-huh.  Still practice a lot of medicine?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I'm on the staff of...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Yes, we've heard that.  Doctor: you testify quite a bit against other physicians?  Isn't that right? You, you're available for that? When you're paid to be there?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Sir.  Yes.  When a thing is wrong...as in this case, I am available.  I am seventy-four years old, I am not board-certified.  I have been practicing medicine for forty-six years and I know when an injustice has been done.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Do you, indeed.  I'll bet you do. Fine.  Fine.  We'll save the court the time.  We will admit the Doctor as an `expert witness,' fine.

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Objection.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Your Honor, Bishop Brophy and the Archdiocese have offered plaintiff two hundred and ten thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Huh!

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: My doctors didn't want a settlement at any price.  They wanted this cleared up in court.  They want their vindication.  I agree with them.  But for today the offer stands.  Before we begin the publicity of a trial.  For today only.    When I  walk out that door the offer is withdrawn.  As long as you understand that.  It's got to be that way.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Concannon...?

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Nothing further, your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Galvin, rebuttal?

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Objection!  This is ri...expect us to accept a photocopy, we have the original right...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I'll rule on that presently.   Proceed.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: No further questions.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: You may step down.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Thank you, your Honor.  We object to the copy of the admissions form as incompetemt and essentially hearsay evidence and cite McGee versus State of Indiana, U.S. 131 point 2 and 216 through 25 of the Uniform Code:  'The admission of a duplicate document in preference to an existing original must presuppose the possibility of alteration and so must be disallowed.'  And, your Honor, having given the Plaintiff the leeway we would like your ruling on this issue now:  we object to the admission of the Xerox form.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: ...one moment, Mr. Concannon...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: The document is disallowed, the jury will be advised not to consider the testimony of Kathy Costello regarding the Xerox form.    It's unsubstantiated and we  can't accept a copy in preference to the original...

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Thank you, your Honor.  Further: Ms. Costello is a rebuttal witness. As a `Surprise Witness' she may only serve to rebut direct testimony.  As her only evidentiary rebuttal was the admitting form, which has been disallowed I request that her entire testimony be disallowed and the jury advised that they must totally disregard her appearance here.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I'm going to uphold that.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You are aware of the penalties for perjury...?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: It's a crime.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Yes.    It is a crime.  A serious crime.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I wouldn't do it.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You would not...?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: In fact, you've just taken an oath that you would not commit perjury. You've just sworn to that.  Isn't that right?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Just now...

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...sworn before God you would tell the truth?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Now.  I'd like to ask you something: four years ago, when you were working as a nurse, are you aware that Drs. Towler and Marx based their treatment of Deborah Ann Kaye on this chart that you signed . . . ?

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: And wasn't that an oath...?  These are your initials here:  K.C. When you signed this chart you took an oath.  No less important than that which you took today.   Isn't that right?   Isn't that right...?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I...yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: Then, please, which is correct? You've sworn today the patient ate one hour ago.  Four years ago you swore she ate nine hours ago? Which is the lie.  When were you lying?

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You know these doctors could have settled out of court.  They wanted a trial.  They wanted to clear their names.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: They lied.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: `They lied.'  Indeed!  When did they lie?  And do you know what a lie is?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I do.  Yes.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You swore on this form that the patient ate nine hours ago.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: That's not my handwriting.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You've just said you signed it.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes, I, yes, I signed it, yes. But I, I didn't write that figure.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: You didn't write that figure.  And how is it that you remember that so clearly after four years?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Because I kept a copy.  I have it right here.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: ...what in the world would induce you to make a photocopy of some obscure record and hold it fouryears?  This is a...why?  Why would you do that?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I thought I would need it.

turns.speaker: CONCANNON
turns.text: And why, please tell us, would you think that?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: After, after the operation, when that poor girl, she went in a coma. Dr. Towler called me in.  He told me he had five difficult deliveries in a row and he was tired, and he never looked at the admittance form.    And he told me to change the form.  He told me to change the one to a nine.   Or else, or else, he said...  He said he'd fire me.  He said I'd never work again....Who were these men...? Who were these men...?  I wanted to be  a nurse...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Please sit down.  I told your wife. I'm sorry that we have to meet out here.  I've got a case coming in two days in the  Superior Court and my office is a mess of papers.

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: ... that's all right.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I was telling your wife, we have a very good case here.

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: ...the Archdiocese called up, they said who was our attorney, 'cause the case is coming to trial...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I doubt we'll have to go to trial ...

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: ... we told them we didn't want it to come out this way.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I completely understand ...

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: We just ...

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: What is this going to cost?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: It's completely done on a contingency basis.  That means whatever the settlement is I retain one-third ...that is, of course, the usual arrangement ...

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: You said you're gonna call me up. You didn't call me up.  Who do you think you are?    Who do you think you are...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Hold on a second.

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: I'm going to have you disbarred. I'm going to have your ticket. You know what you did?  Do you know what you did?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: It's all right, Mickey.

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: You ruined my life, Mister...Me and my wife...and I am going to ruin yours...  You don't have to go out there to see that girl.  We been going four years.    Four years...my wife's been crying herself to sleep what they, what, what they did to her sister.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I swear to you I wouldn't have turned the offer down unless I thought that I could win the case...

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: What you thought!?  What you thought...I'm a workingman, I'm trying to get my wife out of town, we hired you, we're paying you, I got to find out from the other side they offered two hundred...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm going to win this case...Mist...Mr. Doneghy...I'm going to the Jury with a solid case, a famous doctor as an expert witness, and I'm going to win eight hundred thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: You guys, you guys, you're all the same.  The Doctors at the hospital, you...it's 'What I'm going to do for you'; but you screw up it's `We did the best that we could. I'm dreadfully sorry...'  And people like me live with your mistakes the rest of our lives.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: If I could accept the offer right now, I would.  They took it back.

turns.speaker: DONEGHY
turns.text: I understand.    I went to the Bar Association.  They tell me you're going to be disbarred.

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: They gave her the wrong anesthetic.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Why is that?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Her sister said she ate one hour prior to admittance...she...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...that's what the sister said. The chart said she ate nine hours prior to...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: ...she went in complaining of stomach cramps.  Good doctor would have doubted the information on the chart.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Is that what a good doctor would do?  How old are you, please?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I am seventy-four years old.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What qualifies you as an expert in anesthetics?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I am on the staff of...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Easthampton Hospital for Women. Excuse me, what is that, a joke? Let me tell you something, Doctor, those men at Catherine Laboure. Men who are known not only in this city, but the world, were trying to save a woman's life.  They were there, and here you are, four years later, read some hospital report, and say...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: ...I made a detailed physical examination of the patient, Sir, yesterday evening, I...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: She getting good care over there?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Actually, yes.  It's by no means bad, I...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Then what good would it do to ruin the reputation of two men, to help a girl whose life's not going to be changed in the least?   You know what CODE BLUE means?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: 'Code Blue'...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: It's a common medical term.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Are you saying that a failure to restore the heartbeat within nine minutes in itself constitutes bad medical practice?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I...in that small context I would have...I would have to say 'no.'

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Then you're saying there's no negligence, based on my question?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I...given the limits of your question, that's correct.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: The Doctors were not negligent.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Dr. Thompson...?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: It was good of you to meet...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I have some errands to run, and then I thought we'd spend the evening...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: That's what I'd planned to...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm going to take you to the home to see the girl...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: From what I've seen, Mr. Galvin, you have a very good case...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.  Yes.  I think so.  I hope you'll be comfortable.  I'm putting you up at my...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: ...I made a reservation at...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...apartment.   No, no. Please.  You don't know who we're dealing with, I, please believe me, they...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: ...What difference would...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: These people play very rough. They don't want to lose this case. There's a lot of pressure they can bring to bear, I...

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: There's nothing they can do to me.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Dr. Thompson.  From your review of the hospital records of May twelfth nineteen seventy-six.  In your opinion, what happened to Deborah Ann Kaye?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: Cardiac arrest.  During delivery her heart stopped.  When the heart stops the brain's deprived of oxygen.  You get brain damage. That is why she's in the state she's in today.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Now, Dr. Towler's testified that they restored the heartbeat within three or four minutes.  In your opinion is his estimate correct?

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: It's my opinion it took him much longer.  Nine...ten minutes. There's too much brain damage.

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I didn't do too well for you.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No, you did fine.

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: I'm afraid that's not true.   Will you want me to stay on till Monday?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No.  No thank you, Doctor.  You go home.

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: You know...sometimes people can surprise you.  Sometimes they have a great capacity to hear the truth.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes...I...yes.

turns.speaker: DR. THOMPSON
turns.text: You sure you don't want me to stay on.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No.  No.  Thank you. You go home.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Dr. Towler; page 406, 'Contraindications to general anaesthetic.  Ideally a  patient should refrain from taking nourishment up to nine hours prior to induction of general anaesthetic.'  Does that sound familiar?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.  I wrote it.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: 'Practice and Methodology in Anaesthesia.'  General textbook on the subject.  Is  that correct?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: I.  Yes.  It is.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: And you wrote that...

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...Page 414, 'If a patient has taken nourishment within one hour prior to inducement, general anaesthetic should be avoided at all costs because of the grave risk the patient will aspirate food particles into his mask.'  Is that what happened to Deborah  Ann Kaye?  She aspirated into her mask?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: She threw up in her mask, yes. But she hadn't eaten one hour prior to admission.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: If she had eaten, say one hour prior to admission, the inducement of a general anaesthetic...the type you gave her... would have been negligent...?

turns.speaker: DR. TOWLER
turns.text: Negligent.  Yes...it would have been criminal.  But that was not the case.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Dr. Gruber ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: Yes?  Galvin, right?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I appreciate--a man as busy as--

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: That's perfectly all right.  I'm kind of rushed.  Do you mind if we walk while we talk?

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: I read the hospital report on your client.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... Deborah Ann Kaye ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: ... Deborah Ann Kaye ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: They called, they're going to settle, what I want to do is build up as much ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: Right.  Who called?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: The Archdiocese called, they want to settle ... her estate ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: ... and you're going to do that?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: You're going to settle out of court?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Uh ... in the, well, in the interests of her family ... you, Dr. Gruber, you know, you can never tell what a jury is going to do. St. Catherine's a very well thought of institution.  Her doctors ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: Her doctors killed her.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ) I'm sorry ...?

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: Her doctors murdered her.  They gave her the wrong anaesthetic and they put her in the hospital for life.    Her doctors murdered her.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Do you know who her doctors were?

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: I read the file.  Yeah.  Marx and Towler.  I know who they were.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: The most respected ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: Whose side are you arguing ...?  I thought that you wanted to do something.  I don't have any interest in the woman's 'estate' -- No offense, but we all know where the money's going  to ... I have an interest in the Hospital;  and I don't want those bozos working in the same shop as me.  They gave her the wrong anesthetic.  They turned the girl into a vegetable. They killed her and they killed her kid.  You caught 'em.  Now: how many others did they kill?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: The hospital is owned by the Archdioceses of ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: What are they going to do?  Not invite me to their Birthday party ...?   Look, I gotta go.  I have to be in Cambridge ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Well, well, when can we meet again. I'd like to get a deposition..

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: Okay.  I'll meet you here.  Tuesday night ... I gotta go.  You going my way?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: We have to ... we ... we have to keep you under wraps.  Please don't, don't discuss ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... the case with anyone.  And I'll meet you Tuesday, and we'll go over your testimony ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Thank you ...

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: ... that's perfectly all right.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Uh, why, why are you doing this?

turns.speaker: GRUBER
turns.text: To do right.  Isn't that why you're doing it?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm Joe Galvin, I'm representing Deborah Ann Kaye, case against St. Catherine Laboure.

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: I told the guy I didn't want to talk to...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'll just take a minute.  Deborah Ann Kaye.  You know what I'm talking about.  The case is going to trial. Our chief witness is a Dr. David Gruber, you know who he is?

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: He's the Assistant Chief of Anesthesiology, Massachusetts Commonwealth.  He says your doctors, Towler and Marx, put my girl in the hospital for life.  And we can prove that.  What we don't know is why.  What went on in there?  In the O.R.  That's what we'd like to know.  Something went wrong.  And you know what it was.  They gave her the wrong anesthetic.  What happened?  The phone rang...someone got distracted...what?

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: ...you got your doctor's testimony. Why do you need me?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I want someone who was in the O.R. We're going to win the case, there's no  question of that.  It's just a matter of how big...

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: I've got nothing to say to you.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You know what happened.

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: Nothing happened.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Then why aren't you testifying for their side?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I can subpoena you, you know.  I can get you up there on the stand.

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: And ask me what?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Who put my client in the hospital for life.

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: I didn't do it, Mister.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Who are you protecting, then?

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: Who says that I'm protecting anyone?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I do.  Who is it?  The Doctors. What do you owe them?

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: I don't owe them a goddamn thing.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Then why don't you testify?

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: You know, you're pushy, fella...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You think I'm pushy now, wait 'til I get you on the stand...

turns.speaker: MARY ROONEY
turns.text: Well, maybe you better do that, then.   You know you guys are all the same. You don't care who gets hurt. You're a bunch of whores.  You'd do anything for a dollar.  You got no loyalty...no nothing...you're a bunch of whores.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yessir.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Why is that?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I was held up.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Now, have you boys tried to resolve your little difficulty because that certainly would save the Commonwealth a lot of time and bother.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: This is a complicated case, your Honor...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I'm sure it is, Frank:  and let me tell you something.  If we find it so complex, how in the hell you think you're going to make a jury understand it?   See my point?  Let's talk a minute. Frank: what will you and your client take right now this very minute to walk out of here and let this damn thing drop?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: My client can't walk, your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I know full well she can't, Frank. You see the Padre on your way out and he'll punch your ticket.  You follow me?  I'm trying to help you.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: That's it...?    Come on, guys...life is too short...  You tell me if you're playing 'chicken,' or you mean it.    Frank:  I don't think I'm talking out of school, but I just heard someone offer you two hundred grand...and that's a lot of money...and if I may say, you haven't got the best of records.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...things change.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: ...that's true.  Sometimes they change, sometimes they don't. Now, I remember back to when you were disbarred...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I wasn't disbarred, they dropped the pro...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: And it seems to me, a fella's trying to come back, he'd take this settlement, and get a record for himself.    I myself would take it and run like a thief.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm sure you would.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Thank you for seeing me.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: That's perfectly all right.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I need an extension for my case.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: You should have taken their offer. Especially if you were unprepared.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I had a witness disappear on me.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: That happens.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I could subpoena him if I had a week.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I don't have a week.  This case never should have come to trial. You know better.  You're Mr. Independent.  You want to be independent?  Be independent now. I've got no sympathy for you.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Is the Plaintiff ready?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Ready, your Honor.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Defense...?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Do we have time this morning to... All right.  Mr. Galvin, you want to continue now, or we can resume with Dr. Thompson this afternoon.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Thank you, your Honor, I'll continue.  Dr. Thompson.  Did you examine Deborah Ann Kaye last night at The Northern Chronic Care Facility?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Sustained.  Yes.  The witness will confine his testimony to review of the hospital records.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I believe that's the law...is it not, Mr. Galvin...?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Galvin?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: If I may be permitted to question my own witness in my own way...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I'd just like to get to the point, Mr. Galvin.  Let's not waste these people's time.  Answer the question, Mr. Witness.  Please.  Would a nine-minute lapse in restoring the heartbeat in and of itself be negligence?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: I got a letter from the Judge Advocate's office on you today, fella, you're on your way out...They should have kicked you out on that Lillibridge case.  Now this is it today.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm an attorney on trial before the bar.  Representing my client. My client, do you understand?  You open your mouth and you're losing my case for me.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Listen to me, fella...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No, no, you listen to me.  All I wanted in this case is an even shake.  You rushed me into court in five days...my star witness disappears, I can't get a continuance, and I don't give a damn.  I'm going up there and I'm going to try it.  Let the Jury decide.  They told me Sweeney he's a hard-ass, he's a defendant's judge.  I don't care.  I said, the hell with it.  The hell with it. I'll take my chances he'll be fair.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Galvin, look, many years ago...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: And don't give me this shit, 'I was a lawyer, too.'  'Cause I know who you were.  You couldn't hack it as a lawyer. You were Bag Man for the Boys and you still are.  I know who you are.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Are you done?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Damn right I'm done.  I'm going to ask for a mistrial and I'm going to request that you disqualify yourself from sitting on this case. I'm going to take a transcript to the State and ask that they impeach your ass.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: You aren't going to get a mistrial, boy.  We're going back this afternoon, we're going to try this case to an end.  Now you get out of here before I call the Bailiff and have you thrown in jail.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Nothing further, your Honor...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Mr. Concannon...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I object, your Honor...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Overruled...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Exception!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Noted.  Thank you.   Miss Costello was a rebuttal witness.  Her sole rebuttal was the document,  which has been disallowed...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Continental Casualty...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Mr. Alito, please.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Business hours are over, Sir. This is the switch...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I have to reach him.  This is an emergency.  Could you give me his home number?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: I'm sorry, Sir, we're not allowed...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...Would you, would you call him up.  I'll give you my number, and ask him...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: I can't guarantee that...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I understand.  Thank you, my name is Galvin.  I'll be at the following number in a half an hour.  It's urgent.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Mr. Galvin's...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Let me talk to Mickey.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Hello, I'm calling from...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: If you're selling something, I'm late for work...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm calling from Professional Nurse Quarterly...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: From the magazine?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: This is Mr. Wallace in Subscriptions?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: How come you're calling me from...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: This is Miss Costello...?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Yes.  Price...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Pardon?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Kathy Price.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: We find that your subscription lapsed...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: My subscription lapsed three years ago...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That's why I'm calling, Miss Price...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Missus...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: We have a renew-your-subscription offer...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: We get it at work.  We get the magazine at work.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes, we know that you do.  I have it in my files.  That's at the Manhattan Health Center...

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: No.  At Chelsea Childcare.  Okay. Look, call me Monday, hey?  I'm late for work.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: D'you find an apartment?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Still looking.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I changed my life today.  What did you do?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I changed my room at the Hotel.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: The TV didn't work.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What Hotel are you staying at?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: And what are you?  A cop?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm a lawyer.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: My ex-husband was a lawyer.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Really.  How wonderful for you.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yes.  It was, actually.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Oh, actually it was.  Then why'd you call it off?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Who says I'm the one that called it off?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: A brick house says you divorced him.  I'll put you on your honor. Bet you a hundred dollars against you join me for dinner.  And I'll take your word for it.  Now you tell me the truth.  Because you cannot lie to me.  What's your name?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Laura.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: My name's Frank.  And furthermore, you came back to see me tonight.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What if it wasn't you that I came back to see?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You just got lucky.   D'you eat yet?  Come on.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: The weak, the weak have got to have somebody to fight for them. Isn't that the truth?  You want another drink?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I think I will.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Jimmy!  That's why the court exists.  The court doesn't exist to give them justice, eh?  But to give them a chance at justice.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: And are they going to get it?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: They might.  Yes.  That's the point ...is that they might...you see, the jury wants to believe.  They're all cynics, sure, because they want to believe.  I have to go in there tomorrow to find twelve people to hear this case.   I'm going to see a hundred people and pick twelve.  And every one of them it's written on their face, `This is a sham.  There is no justice...' but in their heart they're saying, 'Maybe...maybe...'

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Maybe what?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Maybe I can do something right.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: And is that what you're going to do?    Is that what you're going to do...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That's what I'm going to try to do.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Would you like me to leave...?   Is this a bad time --?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Is this a bad time.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: We, we...No...we just had a small reversal in the case... I have some, uh...I have some work to do...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What happened...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: They, uh, they got to my witness.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: ...and is that serious?
